Week 1 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Vectors

    • Basic Operations
    • Length

  • Parametrizing Lines

Vectors

Basic Operations

A vector (in this class) is an ordered set of numbers. For example, ⟨1,2,2⟩\ang{1, 2, 2}⟨1,2,2⟩ is a 333-dimensional vector and ⟨4,7⟩\ang{4, 7}⟨4,7⟩ is a 222-dimensional one. There are two basic operations:

  1. (vector addition) If v⃗=⟨a1,b1,c1⟩\vec{v} = \ang{a_1, b_1, c_1}v=⟨a1​,b1​,c1​⟩ and w⃗=⟨a2,b2,c2⟩\vec{w} = \ang{a_2, b_2, c_2}w=⟨a2​,b2​,c2​⟩, then v⃗+w⃗=⟨a1+a2,b1+b2,c1+c2⟩\vec{v} + \vec{w} = \ang{a_1 + a_2, b_1 + b_2, c_1 + c_2}v+w=⟨a1​+a2​,b1​+b2​,c1​+c2​⟩.
  2. (scalar multiplication) If v⃗=⟨a,b,c⟩\vec{v} = \ang{a, b, c}v=⟨a,b,c⟩ and λ\lambdaλ is a real number, then λv⃗=⟨λa,λb,λc⟩\lambda\vec{v} = \ang{\lambda a, \lambda b, \lambda c}λv=⟨λa,λb,λc⟩.

In other words, you just do everything coordinate-wise. One thing to notice is that there's no standard way to multiply vectors, so things like v⃗w⃗\vec{v} \vec{w}vw and v⃗w⃗\frac{\vec{v}}{\vec{w}}wv​ are meaningless. Because of this, I strongly recommend putting the little arrows on your vectors so that mistakes are more obvious. For example, say you want to solve λv⃗=w⃗\lambda \vec{v} = \vec{w}λv=w for λ\lambdaλ. If you don't use the arrows, then you might end up writing something like

λ=wv\lambda = \frac{w}{v}λ=vw​

which doesn't really stand out. On the other hand, if you wrote

λ=w⃗v⃗,\lambda = \frac{\vec{w}}{\vec{v}},λ=vw​,

then the problem is a lot more apparent.

Length

If v⃗=⟨a,b⟩\vec{v} = \ang{a, b}v=⟨a,b⟩, then you can draw the following picture:

∥v⃗∥\norm{\vec{v}}∥v∥ denotes the length of v⃗\vec{v}v, and from the Pythagorean theorem, you get

∥v⃗∥=a2+b2.\norm{\vec{v}} = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}.∥v∥=a2+b2​.

Warning: It's not true in general that ∥v⃗+w⃗∥=∥v⃗∥+∥w⃗∥\norm{\vec{v} + \vec{w}} = \norm{\vec{v}} + \norm{\vec{w}}∥v+w∥=∥v∥+∥w∥. For example, if v⃗=⟨1,0⟩\vec{v} = \ang{1, 0}v=⟨1,0⟩ and w⃗=⟨0,1⟩\vec{w} = \ang{0, 1}w=⟨0,1⟩, then

∥v⃗+w⃗∥=∥⟨1,1⟩∥=2\norm{\vec{v} + \vec{w}} = \norm{\ang{1, 1}} = \sqrt{2}∥v+w∥=∥⟨1,1⟩∥=2​

but

∥v⃗∥+∥w⃗∥=1+1=2.\norm{\vec{v}} + \norm{\vec{w}} = 1 + 1 = 2.∥v∥+∥w∥=1+1=2.

Parametrizing Lines

To specify a line, you need two pieces of information. First is a point r⃗0\vec{r}_0r0​ on the line:

From the picture, you can see that one point is not enough. Hopefully, you can see that to uniquely specify a line, I also need to tell you the direction v⃗\vec{v}v that the line passes through:

From here, you can see that if you scale v⃗\vec{v}v, you can get any point on the line. For example:

So you can parametrize the line by

r⃗(t)=r⃗0+tv⃗.\vec{r}\p{t} = \vec{r}_0 + t\vec{v}.r(t)=r0​+tv.

Notice that you have a lot of choices for r⃗0\vec{r}_0r0​ and v⃗\vec{v}v: r⃗0\vec{r}_0r0​ can be any point on the line, and you can replace v⃗\vec{v}v with any (non-zero) scalar multiple of v⃗\vec{v}v. This means that the vector parametrization of a line is not unique.
